awd_titl_txt: Conference: USA-Africa Workshop on Communications and Microwave Emerging Technologies
awd_abstract_narration:
Microwave and communications technologies have propelled the rapid growth of Internet of Things for many emerging industrial and consumer applications, which stimulates new research in the areas of analytical and experimental techniques for device modeling and characterization. This workshop will provide a forum for the multidisciplinary subjects of microwaves and communications engineering to promote interactions and collaborations in research and education among participants. Researchers and students from U.S. will be invited to participate. The outcome is expected to contribute to advancing microwave and communications technologies that will benefit developments of future smart cities and smart villages. The workshop will be held in in Cairo, Egypt, on February 5-6, 2023, and co-located with the IEEE International Microwave & Antennas Symposium (IMAS2023) on February 7-9, 2023. 

This workshop will bring together research scientists, educators, and students to discuss new technological, experimental, computational, and theoretical advances in the processing, characterization, and multi-scale modeling of communication and microwave devices. It will focus on key technological challenges to develop smart cities and smart villages including their wireless infrastructure. The workshop will have multiple sessions with in-depth discussions to cover various research areas that support the developments of future smart cities and smart villages. Four themes/sessions of this workshop are: (1) Technologies for Smart Cities and Smart Villages, (2) Radar Technology for Civilian Applications, (3) Satellite and Space Communications, (4) High-Frequency Semiconductor Devices. The workshop will provide an opportunity for participants to network and explore international collaborations in microwave and communications technologies to benefit the research community and the global society.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The main objective of this project was to organize a workshop called "Microwaves for Humanities" in Cairo, Egypt, from February 5-6, 2023, which aimed to bring together scientists from the USA and Africa.

The German University in Cairo hosted the workshop, while the University of Arkansas was in charge of the organization. Their collaborative efforts ensured the wide participation of scientists from Egypt and other African countries, representing various technical areas related to Smart Cities, Smart Villages, Satellite and Space Communications, and High-Frequency Semiconductor Devices. Subsequently, a closely related event focused on Microwave and Antenna Technologies took place in Cairo. This event, known as IMAS2023, was held from February 7-9, 2023, and involved prominent researchers from IEEE MTT-S and IEEE AP-S.  

The workshop's primary objective was to facilitate in-depth discussions on new technological, experimental, computational, and theoretical advancements in device processing, characterization, and multi-scale modeling. Additionally, it provided a platform for researchers to gain a better understanding of the underlying science behind emerging processes and device applications, such as Gallium Nitride in semiconductor materials.

By bringing together senior and young researchers from all over the world, the workshop promoted interdisciplinary interaction and fostered potential collaborations among participants. The exchange of ideas not only stimulated further collaboration and advancements but also guided junior researchers.

The workshop aimed to encourage cooperative research between American and African scientists in communications and microwave technologies, with the expectation that such collaborations would lead to economic development involving private sectors in both the U.S. and African countries. Overall, the event attracted a diverse group of local, regional, and international participants, providing U.S. scientists with the opportunity to share their cutting-edge research outcomes with African colleagues, engage in dynamic discussions on effective collaborations and idea exchanges, promote research partnerships for the advancement of communications and microwave emerging technologies, and develop strategies and methodologies and investigative techniques to tackle global challenges in the field of communications and microwave technologies.

The Microwave for Humanities workshop was a remarkable event that showcased the latest advancements in various domains. Throughout the workshop, attendees were immersed in a stimulating environment where they could explore cutting-edge experimental and theoretical breakthroughs.  

The Principal Investigators (PIs) firmly believe that the outcomes of the workshop provided valuable insights into how researchers and students from the United States and Africa can collaborate on global research areas and effectively tackle the most challenging technical problems to achieve groundbreaking discoveries. It also demonstrated what strategic roadmap should be developed to ensure more effective and fruitful research outcomes, leveraging diverse talents and perspectives of both parties to address the pressing issues faced by the research community. Additionally, the workshop showcased how sustainable collaborations can be established and maintained, ensuring enduring partnerships that yield significant advancements. Moreover, the Microwave for Humanities workshop explored the role of microwave and communications engineering in solving emerging challenges, such as the development of smart villages. It aimed to enable students from the United States and Africa to access state-of-the-art facilities and work alongside exceptional researchers, benefiting from their expertise. This experience would equip the next generation of scientists to collaborate closely and complement each other's strengths.
